SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Bounty (Injection-moulding Equipment) Amendment Bill 1985. I must say I had thought the Bill would come on for debate a little later this evening, but I am very pleased that a Bill that has had such enthusiastic attention in the lower House is now before us. I think to understand the attitude which is adopted by the Opposition to this Bill, it is necessary to have an examination of the history of the support which has been given to this particular industry over the relatively recent past. Injection-moulding equipment has been reviewed by the Industries Assistance Commission and the Temporary Assistance Authority on at least seven occasions since 1974. Although it is not a massive industry, it is certainly an industry that has received a good deal of attention. The latest IAC report was finalised in 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: Assistance to the industry has been steadily reduced from high levels over the past 10 years or so. There was a tariff of 55 per cent until July 1973 when, of course, the then Government, the Whitlam Government, introduced its 25 per cent across the board tariff cut and that reduced the amount of protection down to 41 per cent. In January 1975 the 55 per cent duty was reinstated, which I suppose tells us something about too sudden changes that come without warning and without a realistic assessment of industry's ability to adjust. That rise in duty in January 1975 back to 55 per cent was because temporary additional duty of 14 per cent was imposed following the report of the Temporary Assistance Authority. In late 1975, following a further Industries Assistance Commission report, the 55 per cent duty was confirmed as the long term duty rate. There was a further Commission report in 1978, and at that time the Government accepted a 15 per cent duty and a recommendation of the Commission that there should be a bounty rate which would start at 45 per cent of value added and reduce by 10 percentage points every year.

Pursuant to the 1978 Industries Assistance Commission report, the Government set a course for this industry which involved its having a diminishing level of protection over a period of years, with the bounty due to terminate in May 1984, leaving the industry with a relatively low rate of tariff protection at 15 per cent. In early 1983 there was a further Temporary Assistance Authority report. Following that report the Government decided to pay an additional bounty of 20 per cent until a long term decision was made. In November 1984-we are getting up to the decisions which are reflected in this legislation-after a further IAC report the Government decided to accept the Commission's recommendations for a duty rate of 15 per cent, with a renewed bounty at 20 per cent of value added for two years and 10 per cent for a further two years.

We have had a series of reports and recommendations and a series of decisions in which various governments have given tariff protection, reduced it, restored it, reduced it and added a bounty, diminished the bounty, restored the bounty, and so on. It is not a particularly encouraging history because, in the face of all that attention and all those decisions and the fairly considerable protection that has been given to the industry, the number of companies involved and the contribution of Australian manufacture to market share have continued to decline. In 1975 there were four manufacturers, with Johns Consolidated Ltd being the largest. By 1983 there was one, that is, a company called Battenfeld (Aust) Pty Ltd, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of a large West German producer. I mention that the only producer is foreign owned but I do not suggest that that should alter the attitude we adopt to the degree of protection it should be granted. I do not think that is a distinction that needs to be drawn or that, in economic terms, is properly made. The fact is that we have one manufacturer, located at Albury, which employs-

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with Borg-Warner, which is selling all the transmissions for all the London taxi cabs. It is one of the success stories.

—That is true. In any event, this company, which is located at Albury, has about 80 employees, only half of whom are involved in the manufacturing process. Production has declined for that company from 28 machines in 1979-80 to 20 machines in 1982-83, although I am advised that production has increased marginally since then. Johns Consolidated, the company which had previously been the largest producer-this is detailed in the IAC report-ceased exports in 1982 and Battenfeld has not exported over the past three years. Again I am advised that the export potential of this industry has increased as a result of a fall in the value of the dollar and a buoyant world market. Imports to Australia have continued at very high levels. In 1979-80, 177 machines were imported, and I remind honourable senators that in that year Battenfeld manufactured 28 machines. In 1981-82, 272 machines were imported, and in that time-I do not have the figure for Battenfeld immediately to hand-imports fell to 186 in 1982-83, when Battenfeld produced 20 machines. The major sources of imports have been West Germany, Japan and Austria. As I said before, the local producers' share of the market continued to decline. It was 67 per cent in 1979-80 and was down to 28 per cent in 1982-83. By late 1982 Battenfeld, the now remaining producer, believed that its share was 16 per cent. It estimates its share to have been 24 per cent in 1983-84 and, under the proposals which are now before us, it plans to reach 40 per cent of the market by 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: I have gone through that history because it seems that we have something of a small example that is worth examination by the Senate as we consider, for the second time in this new Parliament, the issue of industry assistance. It is important to note, in regard to the attitude we take to the Bill, that the Industries Assistance Commission considers that the long term assistance-that is, the 15 per cent tariff that is in place-is a justifiable tariff. The Commission also considers that the economic conditions of the early 1980s adversely affected the industry's adjustment difficulties and that the evidence suggests that local manufacture could eventually be competitive with no more than tariff assistance. The basis of the IAC's recommendation is that there should be this four years of additional bounty assistance to give the remaining company time to become competitive with the tariff assistance of 15 per cent. It is perhaps also worth observing with respect to this industry that in the view of the Commission there are no grounds for additional assistance for defence or strategic reasons.

The Bill has caused some concern to members of the coalition because it gives continued assistance on what appear to us to be the most marginally justified grounds, given the history I have just outlined. Whilst the Opposition does not propose to vote against this legislation, which implements the decision to grant the further bounty assistance, it is a matter that concerned us and we had to consider very carefully the various factors that come into play. The Opposition sees the bounty decision that has been made by the Government as a little puzzling in light of the preferred stance of the Government and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on industry policy. We find, of course, that Senator Button has tended to make clear that he sees the need for Australian industry to become more outward looking. For it to become more outward looking it must be much more competitive in world terms. I would like to quote a number of remarks Senator Button made in October 1984 in an address to the Australian Business Congress to bring out the sort of reasoning that leads me to say that the decision was a little surprising, given the views the Government has adopted towards industry support and restructuring. At that time Senator Button said:
The solution, of course, propagated by the protagonists of the so-called industry debate was to ignore these issues-
these were the various issues he had outlined-

which are positively related to industry's capacity to compete, and to concentrate on raising or lowering the tariff as a means of rectifying these problems. The consequences of this to Australian industry have, in my view, been serious indeed.
He suggested that industry was at the crossroads and that we had to consider new directions. He went on to say:
. . . the essential elements of those new directions must be-
1. To provide a suitable environment for the transition to be made from past policy emphases to new policy emphases;
2. to encourage a number of attitudinal changes;
3. to address the questions of competitiveness to which I referred, and particularly the inhibitions on the competitiveness of Australian industry; and
4. to consider a whole range of Government policies which have relevance to the question of economic growth and industry competitiveness.

I am in broad agreement with the sorts of comments that were made by Senator Button in that speech. Indeed, if we examine the debate that has taken place on this Bill in the House of Representatives, and in particular the speech made by Mr David Connolly, who represents me in the lower House, we see a great deal of attention given to the range of government policies that are of relevance to the question of economic growth and industry competitiveness. It is an unfortunate fact that whilst in opposition we cannot address that great range of issues which do need attention, and that is indeed one of the reasons why we see it as being necessary to support this legislation, or at least not to oppose it-because there is little that we can do to meet the many problems which no doubt Battenfeld, in common with other companies in manufacturing face, whether it is the labour market, the high cost of services or whatever. In any event, I simply make the point that if, as the Government claims, it is concerned with providing an environment for change, and with a general policy framework which is conducive to the restructuring of industry, and also with allowing industry to be internationally competitive, it seems to us that this Bill is evidence that the Government is in fact directing more attention to the traditional issue of protection than it is perhaps to the more fundamental issues which bedevil Australian industry.

I think it is very important that industry debate should not become bogged down into a very arid debate about the precise level of protection which might be required. I am heartened in that view by what was said by the Business Council of Australia in an extensive article which it published in October last year on revitalisation and structural adjustment of the Australian economy. I quote from page 5 of the Business Council Bulletin of October 1984:

When asked specifically to address the issue of reconstruction and revitalisation of Australian industry we took the view that we should not simply perpetuate the old, tired, and inappropriate debate about how much of this or that industry we should have, and the optimum level of protection.
With respect, I think that is a very sound approach for the Business Council to have adopted. I would like to quote two other brief passages from that same document. It said on page 6:

The proper emphasis we believe, for this stage in our country's development, should be on removing obstacles and roadblocks to restructuring and revitalisation and providing appropriate motivation for innovation and enterprise rather than on central determination of sectors for growth or decline, or selective application of policy instruments to achieve desired change.
A little later on, on the same page, it said:
Attitudes and demands which inhibit change, (or make it too expensive) will have a most damaging effect.

Again I would respectfully adopt the sentiments contained in those extracts that I have read. It does seem to me that the sooner we get down to realising that to have a successful industry policy we have to remove the whole series of obstacles and roadblocks that face Australian industry, the better it will be. I think that to concentrate the debate too much on the tariff when those industries which are reliant on tariff protection are subjected to so many other disadvantages within the Australian economy and are not enabled to be more competitive, is a disservice to Australia and certainly will do nothing to advance the interest of manufacturing industry.

I think I have made it clear that the Opposition has very strong doubts that a further extension of bounty is warranted, given the history of tariff and bounty protection and the history of decline in the industry to the point where there is one remaining manufacturer in this country. On the figures shown in the IAC report it appears that the Australian manufacturer has a small proportion of the market although it hopes to expand its share and thereby improve its competitive position, and it hopes to resume exports. In the Opposition's view there are many barriers in the way of Australian manufacturers being competitive. For many industries the most significant barriers lie in the area of labour practices and wages policy. Out-of-date labour practices frequently comprise barriers to efficiency and hence competitiveness. Wage costs are inflated not merely by wage increases unrelated to profitability in any particular enterprise but by the rapidly expanding problem of on-costs, which substantially inflate the true costs of labour. There are substantial other penalties imposed on Australian manufacturing by excessive government charges and costly government services which are provided by government monopolies which are themselves shielded from competition. As a result, the charges for government and semi-government services have consistently risen faster than the general inflation rate. Transport-a substantial cost component in most industries-has its cost inflated by government restrictions, monopolies and duopolies. This is made clear in the Opposition's industry policy. We see an assault on all of these areas as essential if Australian industry is to be made more competitive, and we believe that Australian industry will respond to the challenge of the future only if those barriers are reduced and if the tax burden is reduced so that there is real incentive for investors.

Our reservations about this particular measure of industry assistance can be summarised as follows. First, the protection granted in the past has not succeeded in producing a healthy growing industry, rather the reverse. The number of companies involved in the share of the market has steadily declined. We hope that the more recent information indicates that the decline has been reversed. One would hope that would be the result of this further chance that the industry has been given. Second, the industry being protected is the producer of intermediate goods. By that I simply mean that the goods which are produced by this industry are in fact used by other industries to produce things which are purchased by consumers. Of course any inefficiency in this industry, any unnecessary costs in this industry, will be passed on ultimately to those who use those goods and to the ultimate consumers who follow. It is true, however, that the current Bill, by extending a further bounty, does not inflate the cost of machinery to the downstream producers. The overall tariff-15 per cent-of course does and it must be doubtful whether that is in the interests of the competitive position of the downstream producers. Not that this Bill raises the issue of the tariff directly at all, but one issue which I think always has to be considered in these debates is the extent to which the protection being granted may increase the burden on those who produce goods for ultimate consumption by individuals in the community. The third matter which concerns us is that the number of jobs involved directly in the manufacturing process is very limited. Although, according to the IAC report, the company employs 80 people, perhaps half of those are directly involved in manufacturing.

In light of these points the IAC report is rather puzzling in its recommendation that further protection be extended. Notwithstanding this the Opposition believes that it should not seek to defeat the Government's proposal, although we doubt its wisdom. While we are in opposition we are unable to tackle the many other problem areas that I have mentioned and we are reluctant to impose random elements of our industry policy when we are not in a position to implement the whole. We accept that the bounty proposal is temporary and scales down in the second two years of operation. We would certainly see this as the final opportunity for the industry to establish itself on a competitive basis in Australia and we would expect that this legislation represents the final bounty to the industry.

If I may conclude my speech on a more positive note, I would express the optimistic view that Australian manufacturing industry can prosper and grow. However, I believe it will prosper and grow only if there is a determined government effort to remove the great range of disabilities which currently face Australian industry. The great difficulty for Australian industry at the moment is that it is cursed with a government which has a number of fundamentally defective approaches. It is of course the highest taxing government Australia has seen, and one does not have to spend very much time with industry to know that the tax burden is one important element of industry's problems. We have a government which is unlikely to tackle the monopolies and government regulated transport systems, which add enormously to industry's costs. We have a government which has shown itself to be a prisoner of the prices and incomes accord, no longer a master of its destiny when the Australian Council of Trade Unions' interests conflict with those of the Government. The sad fact of the matter is that the rigid wage system with which industry is afflicted and the rigid maintenance of out-dated labour practices in so many sectors of Australian industry are the sorts of problems which this Government is simply unable to tackle.

One could go on and on in listing the areas which are unlikely to receive effective action from this Government, but it is the view of the Opposition that it is necessary for government to be chasing and in fact achieving results in all these areas if we are to give Australian industry an even chance. It would not be the intention of the Opposition to focus the industry debate on the issue of tariff in the way that perhaps it has been too tightly focused in the past. We believe that the appropriate levels of tariff protection will be properly comprehended by the Parliament, the community and industry itself only when industry is freed from some of the shackles which at present bind it, when its competitiveness is improved in other ways and when it is given a fair deal. It is the intention of the Opposition to press the Government on these matters and to return to government at the next election with a comprehensive industry policy which guarantees a return to competitiveness in Australia in a way that has not been achieved in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Injection-moulding Equipment) Amendment Bill 1985 is, in itself, perhaps a relatively minor piece of legislation. It provides for the continuing payment of a bounty on the value-added components of locally produced injection-moulding equipment and parts thereof. The rate of bounty payment will be 20 per cent in each of the two years after 23 November 1984 and 10 per cent in each of the succeeding two years, concluding on 9 October 1988. The maximum amount to be paid by way of bounty in these four years is limited to $2m. The bounty will be paid almost exclusively to the Albury-based firm, Battenfeld (Aust.) Pty Ltd, which is a 100 per cent owned subsidiary of its German parent company.

SPEECH.PARA: Battenfeld is the only remaining producer of injection-moulding equipment. A decade ago there were about five such producers. Battenfeld was left the field to itself in 1983 when the then only other producer, Johns Consolidated Ltd, went into liquidation. Battenfeld also imports injection-moulding equipment from its parent company. In 1982-83, the last year for which I have statistics, 37 per cent of the value of Battenfeld's sales of injection-moulding equipment comprised the sale of imported equipment. Battenfeld appears to have less than 20 per cent of the Australian market. Imports, primarily from West Germany, Austria, Japan and Italy, comprise the other 80 per cent. Of course, part of that 80 per cent comprises machines imported by Battenfeld.

Battenfeld employs approximately 90 people of whom, as the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, has said, less than half are engaged in the production process. The rest are employed in administration, sales, distribution and servicing. Injection-moulding machines are used by the plastics processing industry. The industry also uses blow-moulding machines. There is a wide range of each of these types of machines. Each type and sub-type has a specific use. In passing I mention that any future inquiry into injection-moulding machines in Australia ought to look at the wider range of machines used in the plastics processing industry. That is the background to the industry, a small industry employing fewer than 100 people and about to enjoy a bounty, provided, of course, at the taxpayers' expense, of a further $2m over the next four years, in addition to a bounty of more than $5m received by the industry over the previous four to five years.

The bounty, although said to be very significant to Battenfeld is minuscule when one considers government spending as a whole. So why did this seemingly minor piece of legislation receive so much attention from the Opposition in the House of Representatives last week, in our Party room and, I might say with some interest, in the Press? It seems to me to have received this attention for two main reasons. The first is that, quite frankly, the Government has made what can only be judged to be an absurd decision in this matter. I will come back to that in some detail in a moment. The second reason is that the Opposition is using this Bill, as it will use similar opportunities, to make known its views on industry restructuring and on the policies it will adopt when it returns to government in 1988, 1987 or earlier if the Government's recent performances are any indication.

Before coming back to the specific substance of the matter before the Senate, I shall comment briefly on some of the media reporting of the matter that has occurred in recent days. Comments in respected newsletters such as Inside Canberra, in business journals such as the Business Review Weekly, and in daily newspapers such as the Australian Financial Review and the Australian today have given the impression that there has been some battle or division within the coalition parties on this issue, that somehow there has been a fight between the so-called dries and the so-called wets within the Opposition. Incidentally, such terms have no sensible meaning. They really should be discarded in the context of any professional analysis of different streams of thought within the coalition parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Won't either group let you in?

—Senator Gareth Evans would be a notable absentee from both groups. Media reports of a split in the Opposition parties on this bounty proposal are, in my view as a closely involved participant, being chairman of the Opposition's industry, technology and commerce committee, simply not correct. There was no opposition amongst coalition members to the view that the Government's decision to continue the bounty arrangement is a bad decision. There was no opposition to the view that if the coalition parties had been in government we would certainly not have made the same decision as the Labor Government has made. There was no opposition to the view that the coalition parties should not positively endorse the Government's decision.

SPEECH.PARA: There was debate on the question of how best to handle the Bill from a parliamentary point of view. We had two options. One was formally to oppose the Bill. The other was to allow its passage but to register our concern and use the occasion to draw attention to the stupidity of the specific decision and to some relevant broader issues. The coalition parties chose the second option for several reasons. Those reasons included considerations relating to the conduct of the Senate, the fact that the Bill relates only to the bounty element of the assistance provided to the industry and does not cover the 15 per cent tariff duty which also protects the industry, the relevance to this industry of the Industries Assistance Commission's still to be completed inquiry into the chemical and plastics industries and the fact that there is no precedent for defeating such a single-issue industry assistance measure as this. So the specific handling of this Bill in the Parliament was a matter of judgment. However, I repeat: There was no split on the correctness or otherwise of the Government's decision. We think it is a bad decision. We also doubt whether the recommendations of the IAC which the Government accepted were in line with the argumentation and logic contained in the IAC's own report.

I shall look now at the history of this industry and its treatment by government. I believe that it is a classic case of the application of protection to a new or infant industry which has continued over the years even though the infant has failed to grow up. It is a classic case of how not to go about the sensible and viable development of the Australian manufacturing sector. The industry has been the subject of five IAC inquiries and two Temporary Asistance Authority inquiries in the past 10 years-that is, seven inquiries in 10 years. Prior to 1973, the industry enjoyed tariff protection of 55 per cent. In July 1973 that figure was reduced to 41 per cent as a result of the Whitlam Government's 25 per cent across the board tariff cut. However, in July 1975 the tariff was restored to 55 per cent following a TAA inquiry. Later in 1975 the IAC recommended a reduction in the tariff to 25 per cent, phased in over four years. The Government, however, rejected that recommendation and retained the duty at 55 per cent.

In 1979 the IAC recommended that the tariff be reduced to 15 per cent but that a 45 per cent bounty be introduced, which bounty should reduce by 10 per cent each year to 5 per cent in 1983 and to nil in May 1984, leaving thereafter only the tariff assistance of 15 per cent. The then Government accepted this recommendation. In 1982, however, the industry, which then totalled only two firms-Johns Consolidated and Battenfeld-sought additional temporary assistance. In January 1983 the TAA recommended that additional temporary assistance was not justified, but the Government rejected this advice and in June 1980 granted an additional temporary bounty of 20 per cent, making a total bounty of 25 per cent because the industry still had the previous long term 5 per cent bounty. It had that bounty in addition to the 15 per cent tariff, pending the outcome of the full IAC inquiry to follow.

The IAC inquiry was completed in 1984. It recommended that the 15 per cent tariff be retained and that a 20 per cent bounty apply for each of the next two years, reducing to 10 per cent for each of the subsequent two years and terminating completely in October 1988. The Government accepted this recommendation, and it is the bounty element of the Government's decision which is the subject of the Bill we are now debating. So what the Government is doing in this Bill is to maintain the additional temporary bounty granted in 1983 but at a slightly lower level for the next two years-20 per cent compared with 25 per cent-before reducing it to 10 per cent in 1987 and 1988.

The bounty is now scheduled to terminate in October 1988 rather than in May 1984, as was envisaged in the earlier 1979 government decision. In other words, this decision represents a considerable increase in the long term protection afforded the industry between 1983 and 1988 despite the fact that most of that protection will terminate on that date. One would be entitled to assume that there are good arguments for such a generous decision, but search as I might, I can find none. The main argument advanced by the IAC seems to be that the sole remaining producer, Battenfeld, will be able to achieve sufficient market share over the next three or so years to be able to compete effectively with imports by the end of 1988 with the assistance of only a 15 per cent tariff and that therefore the bounty assistance is justified in the interim. Where is the evidence to support this optimism? I find it difficult to see any. Battenfeld is looking to achieve a market share of 40 per cent. That would require more than a doubling of its present market share, a share which has declined progressively over the past several years. So a 40 per cent market share is extremely unlikely. Even if Battenfeld did double its output, on its own evidence, its costs would fall by only 13 per cent. That is hardly dramatic.

In 1974 when there were still several local producers, they argued for short term assistance on the grounds that it would allow them to implement rationalisation plans and to become more competitive. It did not happen. In 1975 they argued that higher long term protection was justified to enable them to undertake necessary re-organisation. It did not happen. In 1978 the IAC accepted that continuing high assistance was justified because the then two remaining producers said they were rationalising their activities to become more competitive with imports at a lower level of assistance. They cited specific details of planned research and development production and export programs. These did not happen; on the contrary, one of the two firms, Johns, went broke in 1983 and the remaining firm, Battenfeld, ceased exporting in 1981.

Battenfeld has been struggling to survive even with the generous assistance provided by users and by the general taxpayer. In recent years the company's profitability, even with this assistance, has been about one-fifth of the average for manufacturing industry in Australia. In other words, the highly generous assistance provided to this industry over many years has not improved its relative competitiveness-its market share has been progressively eroded-nor has it assisted employment in the industry. Employment has fallen progressively for more than a decade. Battenfeld acknowledged at the IAC inquiry that it has limited prospects of utilising latest technologies and no scope for introducing the latest computerised numerically controlled machine tools with robotic handling systems. The IAC in its latest report on the industry stated:
. . . there appears to be little scope for further improvement to the structure of the industry.

There is virtually no prospect of developing an export market, with the possible exception of New Zealand. Perhaps the most damning paragraph in the IAC's latest report, which the Government has accepted, is to be found on page 17. It states:

In evidence to previous inquiries, local producers claimed that they had restructuring and developmental plans in train that would enable local manufacture to become competitive with imports at more moderate levels of assistance. Battenfeld now claims, however, that it needs assistance of the same order as recommended in the Commission's 1978 report for a further period of five years commencing 1984, ''to achieve the aims envisaged by the 1979 decision of the Government''.

Surely, the above facts provide very strong evidence that this bounty proposal to give Battenfeld a further $2m of taxpayers' money over the next four years-that is about $28,000 per person employed by the company-is simply a classic case of throwing good money after bad. But there are other facts which should be brought out too. In the past few days I have spoken with three plastic processing firms which, collectively, were large users of Battenfeld injection moulding machines. One of the three firms, Fallshaw Holdings Pty Ltd, was willing to have its name mentioned by me this evening. The other two preferred to remain unidentified. All three had the same story to tell independently of each other. In summary, they said that, firstly, they would never buy a Battenfeld machine again. They would not do so for three main reasons, the first being that in many cases the machines were overpriced; the second, that in most cases the machines were inferior in quality to imported machines; and, the third and most important reason was that Battenfeld's maintenance and servicing facilities were totally unsatisfactory in quality of servicing, due partly to demarcation disputes amongst unionised service employees from different unions and, partly, to the lack of skills of those employees. There were also delays in obtaining emergency spare parts because of Battenfeld's policies on holding stocks in Australia. Two of the three firms said: 'Battenfeld has gone backwards as a company over the past two years'. Machine reliability is of critical importance to users. All three firms now consider that they have this reliability, which they did not have with Battenfeld.

Another consideration which should be taken into account is the very real need in Australia to avoid taxing the inputs to user industries in the form of raw materials and intermediate goods. The plastics industry in Australia suffers from very high raw material costs because of the protection afforded local manufacturers. New Zealand plastics manufacturers, for example, pay 50 per cent less than Australian manufacturers for their raw materials because the New Zealanders can buy on the world market. Injection-moulding machines, to which the 15 per cent tariff applies, are another added cost burden, yet the plastics industry in Australia employs 30,000 to 33,000 people, compared with fewer than 100 in the injection-moulding machine industry.

The tremendous wage and wage-related costs experienced by Australian manufacturers, including Battenfeld, of course, as a result of the failure of the Government to do anything to tackle the iniquitous wage rigidities that confront Australian producers, are another major cost obstacle for our manufacturing sector. Unless the Government starts to adopt a coherent approach towards its overall economic management and industry policies-I take Senator Chaney's point that it should include not just assistance policies-and unless it takes a firm approach to its wages and industrial relations policies, no amount of the fine talk or rhetoric that we have become accustomed to hearing from Government Ministers will do one jot towards restructuring industry in Australia to put it on a viable, internationally competitive base. I say to the Government that it is time to stop the fine talk and get on with some action. When the Government does take action, I hope it is more logical and reasoned than the action envisaged in this Bill.

Senator Chaney said earlier that the Opposition looks forward to continuing to participate in debates of this nature on industry policy in Australia. There are few more serious and important issues facing this country. We will obviously have our differences of view as to the best way of tackling the problems that lie ahead, but the encouraging start we have made in recent weeks in opening up the debate, in this chamber and elsewhere, is a good sign, and I hope we will be able to continue in the vein in which we have commenced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The history of the Australian manufacture of injection-moulding machines has not been a happy one. Events over the last 10 years have seen the demise of employment and the exodus of manufacturers, to the point where there is but one company left, Battenfeld (Aust.) Pty Ltd. This company is reputed to apply high technology techniques, but it is not so up to date as to use, for example, computer technology in controlling its machines. However, there are some aspects where this sole producer of injection-moulding machines has not really lived up to some of its undertakings or maintained some of the high standards that are now expected of a modern manufacturer operating in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bounty (Injection-moulding Equipment) Amendment Bill, by allowing the maintenance of a 15 per cent tariff and at the same time extending bounty assistance, adopts the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission. We on this side of politics believe that it is only right that appropriate protective measures applying in a manufacturing sector are not withdrawn suddenly or without adequate notice. Naturally, there has always been some concern over the level of assistance to industry, which is not always defence-related. On the other hand, we have to recognise that the sole operator left is a decentralised firm which operates away from the capital cities. I think it is appropriate that the Government give further consideration to some of the social, as well as economic aspects of its decision-making on protection and to who can survive and who cannot.

It concerns me that industry debates are dominated by an undue attention to the tariff. It seems that these debates are unbalanced in that so many commentators, economists and others seem to apply this notion of protection exclusively to the manufacturing sector and conveniently ignore the myriad of protective mechanisms that are available, for example, in the tertiary sector-transport, public services and so on. It is unfortunate that some commentators and editors have taken the speech of the honourable member for Bradfield, Mr Connolly, and given it a bias towards what they term a 'dry Liberal philosophy', which few of us in this Party could detect in that speech. Mr Connolly's approach and address was most balanced. In today's Australian one writer tried to create a great deal of mischief in this area. I know that my colleague the honourable member for Bass, Mr Warwick Smith, has a more balanced view than that portrayed by Mr David O'Reilly. We sometimes wonder where they get their information.

It is always expected that there will be robust debate about appropriate directions in the trade area. The fact that Australian manufacturers export only 8 per cent of their production indicates just how far the manufacturing industry here is behind other comparable countries with similar living standards. For example, in Scandinavian countries manufacturers often have over 50 per cent of their production exported. When we examine goods and services exported as a percentage of gross domestic product, we note that Australia ranks twenty-first of the 24 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. It is interesting that in this OECD comparison it is the smallest countries that are the most open to foreign trade which perhaps have the best performances. Luxembourg, Belgium, Holland, Ireland, Norway, Austria, Iceland, Denmark, Switzerland, Sweden, Finland, West Germany, New Zealand, Britain, Italy, Canada, Portugal, France and Spain all rank well above Australia. We must encourage our manufacturers to become more export-orientated. In so doing, we must create a climate within which they can operate to develop their full potential as exporters. We must encourage them to apply high technology to their present practices. The emphasis by the present Government appears to be on trying to get new technology industries at the expense of encouraging existing industries to apply high technology practices. There is, therefore, a need for a great deal of deregulation to occur.

We recognise that Australia is a high cost country. It is not only our high wage costs that are a problem for our exporters. Some of those countries I mentioned earlier, such as Switzerland and the Scandinavian countries, are also high cost countries but at the same time, they are high exporters in terms of GDP and percentage of production to export. The difference between Australia and those countries is in productivity. Our productivity is low. We also have a very high on-cost which is impeding progress. On the other hand, I believe the trade union movement has a very heavy cross to carry in this area because all too often it has taken advantage of some of the protective mechanisms that have applied in order to unduly enhance the level of wages to the point where, in terms of the IAC, industries have suddenly become uneconomic in the course of time. There is a need for some deregulation, but the important feature is the lack of emphasis which we in Australia put on productivity. We are falling behind in our standard of living.

The direction of our future trade is very much towards Asia. In Asia they are concentrating on wealth creation rather than wealth distribution. We must change our priorities. It seems strange that Government members should be talking about imposing capital taxes because at the very time that we want industry to be restructured a capital gains tax will lock industries in to existing occupations, rather than allowing the money to flow to higher risk and new areas. Therefore, capital gains tax is restrictive; it locks industries in to existing businesses rather than allowing capital to flow to new areas because of the high cost of the tax. It seems strange that a Labor Party in Australia favours a capital gains tax which inevitably encourages foreign investment to move in and take over because of the lack of ability of Australians to accumulate capital through savings and apply it to investment processes. The emphasis must come back to capital.

Given the future direction of Australian trade, which is towards the Pacific area and the new economies of Asia-for example, Taiwan had the highest growth in gross domestic product per capita last year of more than 10 per cent-our standards of living are falling. The trend of the trade indices is disturbing. Our high interest rates will cause problems of declining profitability. This change in the mix of trade, of our exports and imports, away from Europe and towards Asia, means that unless we can develop a stronger manufacturing base, there will be enormous employment problems. If we apply the strict theory of comparative costs, Australia, which is good at producing minerals, an area where commodity prices are often low and unstable, and which is good at producing agricultural products, can, it is true, sell some of these products to Asia and, in turn, can import Asian manufactures at a comparative advantage. But the question is: What will we do with that large section of often unskilled people in Australia? It was the manufacturing base which enabled us to sustain the large increases in our population following World War II. We must be very careful that we do not completely abandon our manufacturing industries to the detriment of a more open economy. We must open it up more than we have in the past, but we must do it appropriately. It must not be done too dramatically because in the process of change, if it is too severe, people get hurt in the meantime. I believe that we will continue to have robust debates on these matters but I appeal to the media to make sure that they present an accurate and balanced view of any party's position in relation to this debate.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

SPEECH.PARA: One extraordinary thing that has been mentioned in the second reading speech is the fact that, as I recall, in 1983 the Department of Defence indicated that it felt that as a matter of defence capacity it was essential that we have an injection-moulding manufacturing establishment in Australia. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a little to what has been said. In addressing the short title of the Bill, I wish to speak about some of the more general questions involved. When we are debating some of these measures designed to provide bounties or tariff protection of one form or another to industries which have problems, there is a tendency to forget that there are also industries in Australia which have done a tremendous job in placing Australia at the forefront of industrial development. There are industries in Australia which do not require any special protection either by way of bounties or by way of tariffs. When I was listening to Senator Short, I thought: 'What better example could one have? There is Senator Short who until recently was involved in a company which used to enjoy about 300 per cent protection but which has now ceased to need the sort of protection which it was getting and has come down the scale. Improvement is taking place'. These sorts of changes are encouraging. I am referring to sheet glass.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be hard to find anything more typical of London than a London taxi cab. Yet the new London taxi cabs all have a transmission which was made at Albury-Wodonga. When one thinks of that, one starts to think that there is another success story for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be because they are old London taxi cabs in the sense of technology.

—They do a rather good job. We can look at some of the other things which Borg-Warner (Aust) Ltd at Albury is doing in competing in the American markets. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, will be as familiar as I am with the details. We can look at the case of Germany, a country of high technology, particularly in relation to its application to machinery and motor vehicles. A very large number of Germans are driving around Germany in motor vehicles which have an engine made at Fishermens Bend in Australia.
—Competitively, in world terms, or as a result of intra-corporate trade?

—This is the thing that I wanted to come to. This is the part that I wanted to talk about-the unreality of the debate which can take place if one is not careful and one talks in straight terms of what is protection given by one country. When one thinks of the number of non-tariff measures which could be introduced-some 22,000 have been identified altogether, ranging from health restrictions to safety restrictions-and which are supposed to be for one purpose but which are as often as not for another purpose entirely, one starts to realise that the debate can be very sterile if we do not recognise that what has been done in this country has resulted in the development, notwithstanding considerable difficulties, of a very effective manufacturing industry in many areas. We have also developed a manufacturing industry which needs to be brought into the real world of competition and given an opportunity to compete.

SPEECH.PARA: This is where another important part of the debate needs to take place. We need to look at the conditions under which companies operate, in trade terms, in employment terms, in transport terms, in insurance terms and-I come to the interjection by Senator Button-at the intracorporate relationships where there are multinationals operating in a variety of countries and where it is very difficult to be able to say that the trade figures, which are apparent on the face of them between one country and another, really reflect the capacity of the industry in that country to produce competitively as if it were able to operate in a cocoon. It cannot. As my colleague Senator Watson said, too often industry debates tend to be subject to undue attention to tariffs. We should be looking at things such as employment conditions, whether penalty rates apply, what sorts of insurance arrangements and transport arrangements apply, what sorts of opportunities there are for transfers and what sorts of opportunities there are for the companies and those involved in the total amount of trade to be able to engage in practices which can make figures appear to be quite different from what they would be were it not for the engagement in those practices.

We are talking about a company which has obviously had a chequered history. I accept what Senator Short has said, what my Leader, Senator Chaney, has said and what Senator Button has said, that here is a company which most people would regard as testing the limits of one's patience but for which there is a reason for continuing to say: 'Let us give it a further opportunity'. That is the attitude that has been adopted. But what we also need to do is to say, while we are talking about that, that this is not typical of what manufacturing industry in Australia is about. It is also about leading the world in a number of areas. It is also about leading the world in competition, given a fair go. It is also about our trying to change our domestic policies so that our manufacturers have an opportunity to be able to compete in the world. When I have heard the Minister talk about things such as penalty rates and some of the other problems, I have been encouraged to think that we may be able to compete on a basis which is fair and comparable with that of other countries.

I mention here the Poitiers principle, which related to what the French did to the Japanese in regard to videos. They required videos to be taken in through the city of Poitiers which, as everyone knows, is well away from the coast and which had one customs station. All the trucks that were bringing in videos had to line up there and it took a very long time to get through. If we were to apply the same sort of principle, we could adopt a policy in which we gave absolutely no tariff protection to motor vehicles but under which we required them to come in through Port Hedland and be driven to the point of sale. But we have not done that. I believe we have been one of the most honest and straightforward countries and one which has done the least to engage in the sorts of sleight of hand and back door methods of providing protection. I do not think that some of the criticisms that I hear of Australia are entirely fair. I refer to the extent that we have not engaged in the indirect non-tariff measures of protection, but have reduced the up front obvious tariff measures. I give credit to the previous Labor Government for what it did, as well as to the former Liberal and National Party coalition governments for what they have done over a period, and to what the present Government through the present Minister is doing. This country is doing something of which we can be proud, but we are not giving enough encouragement to many of the people who would like to have a go, who would like to be able to try to compete in the manufactured goods world. As probably the best positioned country in a variety of ways in the major growth area of the world, we have an opportunity to take advantage which is second to none.

I read of the growth that is taking place in relation to the telecommunications industry, and I think of what is happening with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Telecom Australia, and the extent to which, perhaps, we ought to be paying a little more attention to the huge growth that will take place there and the impact that decisions they will take will have on the future of Australian manufacturing production. I then start to think about the complaint being made now by the National Farmers Federation, suggesting that too much protection is given to Australian industry. I have regard to the fact that the publication of the Department of Trade, 'Australian Basic Trade Statistics', points out not only that has there been a very significant reduction in the average effective rate of assistance afforded to Australian manufacturers, but also that the average effective rate of assistance afforded to Australian agricultural activities in 1981-82, which is the latest year for which the figures are available, was 9 per cent, having been reduced from 21 per cent 10 years previously.

Then one thinks of what Europe and its common agricultural policy have done to Australia and the extent to which the Europeans have provided effective protection. One finds that whilst we have gone in one direction, some of our major competitors have gone in the very opposite direction. Whilst they have destroyed our sugar market, we have played the game and have seen our sugar producers placed in the most incredibly difficult position.

I do not want to trespass by talking for too long to the short title of the Bill. I wanted to talk briefly about bounties, because it is important that we recognise that whilst we are providing bounties occasionally to some industries that have some problems, we also have some sectors of the manufacturing industry that are doing extremely well. I refer, in conclusion, to one industry that was mentioned earlier today-the manufacture of cricket balls. It happens to be an area of manufacture for which Australia has developed an expertise and a major percentage of the world market. One of the members of the family that has been the chief producer of cricket balls for the world spent five years working out the technology necessary to convert from hand sewing to machine sewing. That was a five-year investment by that family company, leading to a situation in which Australia has been able to continue to hold its leading world position as the manufacturer of cricket balls, as well as in the manufacture of other sporting equipment. But again, it is something that we have done extremely successfully.

One could go on to talk about all of these sides when talking about a bounty Bill. I believe that we tend to concentrate too much on talking about the failures and the problem areas and not enough on talking about some of the areas in which, with a bit of encouragement, we would find that we would get a greater recognition, in either world leadership or the opportunity to get close to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to repeal the National Welfare Fund Act 1943. Welfare and social service payments presently met from a trust account ledger head called the National Welfare Fund will in future be met directly from standing appropriations of the Consolidated Revenue Fund under the specific acts authorising the particular payments.

The National Welfare Fund was established as a trust account by the National Welfare Fund Act 1943 with amounts provided from general revenue, as a vehicle for making various welfare and social security payments. From 1945 funds to meet these payments were provided from social security levies specifically earmarked for this purpose. However, in 1952 the legislation governing the National Welfare Fund was amended to permit the National Welfare Fund to receive funds directly from the Consolidated Revenue Fund equal to whatever expenditure had to be met from the National Welfare Fund. The amounts provided for welfare and social service payments were thus no longer directly linked to levies. The National Welfare Fund effectively then became no more than a ledger head in the accounts through which payments were made. So, in other words, since 1952, expenditure on welfare, although made through this account, did not depend on it for funds.

It was a policy decision of the Government of the day which determined how much would be spent on welfare, and has been so ever since. From 1976 there has been no continuing balance in the National Welfare Fund and payments from it have been matched simultaneously by payments into it from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The process of transferring funds into a special account which are then simultaneously paid out of it has been time consuming and wasteful of scarce resources. It has been criticised by the Auditor-General in his report for the year ended 30 June 1981 as a mechanism that served no useful function entailing significant and unnecessary accounting work.
The Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations have been consulted and agree that the National Welfare Fund serves no useful purpose.

The new accounting procedures are designed only to remove an inefficient and anachronistic process and are consistent with other initiatives by the Government to improve financial management in government.

The change to the accounting procedures has no bearing on policy issues relating to welfare payments, i.e., the way in which recipients are paid, or the quantum of funds allocated by the Government to social welfare. I would like to stress this: These changes will have absolutely no effect on the amounts available to the Government for social security purposes.
Other than the administrative savings which will result from the new procedures this legislation has no financial impact.

It is intended that clauses 1, 2 and 5 of this Bill, which provide the mechanism for the continuing payment of welfare and social security benefits, come into operation on the day the Bill receives royal assent. The remaining clauses of this Bill will come into operation on a day to be fixed by proclamation, the tentative target being 1 July 1985.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
